Keep a running list of questions we can ask people/friends for advice.Suchita: can't prevent t-channel DM from decaying, because loop-induced decays would still be there. Suchita about Z2: we impose Z2 because we don't really have a natural way to make DM stable on the scale of Universe, and in the WIMP regime that's the easiest way known. One can also try to arrange for mass hierarchies such that Z2 is not required.

? Also this wants a new neutrino in the game. Could also think of

"The U(1)B−L extension of the Standard Model requires the existence of right- handed neutrinos and naturally realizes the seesaw mechanism of neutrino mass generation." and then they add an extra scalar on top of the Z_BL that can serve as DM. This may go in the "extra candidates" as it seems fairly minimal, but it's singling out a model over others? Maybe just talk briefly about the attractiveness of fixing both neutrino masses and DM at once? PDG also says: The seemingly most obvious WIMP candidate is a heavy neutrino. However, an SU(2) doublet neutrino will have too small a relic density if its mass exceeds MZ/2, as required by LEP data. One can suppress the annihilation cross section, and hence increase the relic density, by postulating mixing between a heavy SU(2) doublet and some sterile neutrino. However, one also has to require the neutrino to be stable; it is not obvious why a massive neutrino should not be allowed to decay.
Note this is a simplified model as it is not SU(2)xU(1) invariant, but one can simply add couplings of DM to the Higgs boson as well and not need any more particles.

Infinite number of possibilities. Are there other consequences to the model, is it just MET at the LHC? Or are there visible particles? How specific are the predictions about the numbers/energy distributions and so forth? The more specific/complicated those things are, the more handles you have to do a search, the more sensitive the search can be. If the prediction is that you always get a WIMP LSP with 4 top quarks with a given invariant mass, then you can use that in the search. Conversely you have a specific search that can catch less. Sensitivity vs generality problem. We start with more general searches with fewer handles. Focus on specificity of signatures rather than classifications of other models.

Spin 3/2 Fermion: Gravitino G ̃ (12) Spin 1/2 Fermions: B ̃, W ̃ , H ̃u, H ̃d
Neutralinos χ1, χ2, χ3, χ4 (13) Spin 0 Scalars: Sneutrinos ν ̃e, ν ̃μ, ν ̃τ . (14)
As indicated, the neutral spin 1/2 fermions mix to form four mass eigenstates, the neu- tralinos. The lightest of these, χ

χ1, is a WIMP dark matter candidate (35; 36). The sneutrinos are not good dark matter candidates, as both their their annihilation and scat- tering cross sections are large, and so they are under-abundant or excluded by null results from direct detection experiments for all masses near mweak (37; 38). The gravitino is not a WIMP, but it is a viable and fascinating dark matter candidate, as discussed in Secs. IV and VI.

Feng AR: None of these SM particles is a good dark matter candidate. Most of the matter particles are unstable, with lifetimes far shorter than the age of the Universe. The remaining particles are the six lightest: the electron, the up and down quarks, which may form stable protons and neutrons in nuclei, and the three neutrinos. Electrons may contribute significantly to dark matter only if they are neutralized through binding with protons, but protons (and neutrons) contribute to the baryonic energy density ΩB, which is too small to be all of dark matter. In addition, current upper bounds on neutrino masses from particle physics and cosmology imply that the neutrino relic density Ων
i mνi /47 eV
< 0.012 (14). The evidence for dark matter therefore requires particles beyond the SM.
"Long-lived, non-interacting" excludes most of them already
Downsides of the model:
If you don't see the particle then you don't see it. Raman at SEARCH
